t: Isaiah 1
Rebellion of God’s People
The*p vision of Isaiah the son of Amoz concerning Judah and Jerusalem, which he saw during the reigns of Uzziah, Jotham, Ahaz and*i Hezekiah, kings of Judah.
Listen,*pn O heavens, and hear, O earth; For*ln the Lord*s speaks, “Sons*ln I have reared and brought up, But*ln they have revolted against Me.
An*ln ox knows its owner, And*ln a donkey its master’s manger, But*iln Israel does not know, My*ln people do not understand.”

Alas,*ln sinful nation, People*ln weighed down with iniquity, Offspring*ln of evildoers, Sons*ln who act corruptly! They*ln have abandoned the Lord,*s They*ln have despised the Holy One of Israel, They*ln have turned away from Him.
Where*ln will you be stricken again, As*iln you continue in your*i rebellion? The*ln whole head is sick And*ln the whole heart is faint.
From*ln the sole of the foot even to the head There*ln is nothing sound in it, Only*iln bruises, welts and raw wounds, Not*ln pressed out or bandaged, Nor*ln softened with oil.
Your*ln land is desolate, Your*ln cities are burned with fire, Your*ln fields—strangers are devouring them in your presence; It*ln is desolation, as overthrown by strangers.
The*ln daughter of Zion is left like a shelter in a vineyard, Like*ln a watchman’s hut in a cucumber field, like a besieged city.
Unless*ln the Lord*s of hosts Had*ln left us a few survivors, We*ln would be like Sodom, We*ln would be like Gomorrah.
God Has Had Enough
Hear*pn the word of the Lord,*s You*ln rulers of Sodom; Give*ln ear to the instruction of our God, You*ln people of Gomorrah.

“What*ln are your multiplied sacrifices to Me?” Says*ln the Lord.*s “I*ln have had enough of burnt offerings of rams And*ln the fat of fed cattle; And*ln I take no pleasure in the blood of bulls, lambs or goats.
When*ln you come to appear before Me, Who*ln requires of you this trampling of My courts?
Bring*ln your worthless offerings no longer, Incense*ln is an abomination to Me. New*ln moon and sabbath, the calling of assemblies— I*ln cannot endure iniquity and the solemn assembly.
I*ln hate your new moon festivals*i and your appointed feasts, They*ln have become a burden to Me; I*ln am weary of bearing them.*i
So*ln when you spread out your hands in*i prayer,*i I*ln will hide My eyes from you; Yes,*ln even though you multiply prayers, I*ln will not listen. Your*ln hands are covered with blood.
“Wash*ln yourselves, make yourselves clean; Remove*ln the evil of your deeds from My sight. Cease*ln to do evil,
Learn*ln to do good; Seek*ln justice, Reprove*ln the ruthless, Defend*ln the orphan, Plead*ln for the widow.
“Let Us Reason”
“Come*pn now, and let us reason together,” Says*ln the Lord,*s “Though*ln your sins are as scarlet, They*ln will be as white as snow; Though*ln they are red like crimson, They*ln will be like wool.
If*ln you consent and obey, You*ln will eat the best of the land;
But*ln if you refuse and rebel, You*ln will be devoured by the sword.” Truly,*ln the mouth of the Lord*s has spoken.
Zion Corrupted, to Be Redeemed
How*pn the faithful city has become a harlot, She*ln who*i was full of justice! Righteousness*ln once lodged in her, But*ln now murderers.
Your*ln silver has become dross, Your*ln drink diluted with water.
Your*ln rulers are rebels And*ln companions of thieves; Everyone*ln loves a bribe And*ln chases after rewards. They*ln do not defend the orphan, Nor*ln does the widow’s plea come before them.
Therefore*ln the Lord God*s of hosts, The*ln Mighty One of Israel, declares, “Ah,*ln I will be relieved of My adversaries And*ln avenge Myself on My foes.
I*ln will also turn My hand against you, And*ln will smelt away your dross as with lye And*ln will remove all your alloy.
Then*ln I will restore your judges as at the first, And*ln your counselors as at the beginning; After*ln that you will be called the city of righteousness, A*ln faithful city.”
Zion*ln will be redeemed with justice And*ln her repentant ones with righteousness.
But*ln transgressors and sinners will be crushed together, And*ln those who forsake the Lord*s will come to an end.
Surely*ln you will be ashamed of the oaks which you have desired, And*ln you will be embarrassed at the gardens which you have chosen.
For*ln you will be like an oak whose leaf fades away Or*ln as a garden that has no water.
The*ln strong man will become tinder, His*ln work also a spark. Thus*ln they shall both burn together And*ln there will be none to quench them.*i
